subject: RE: [junit] testing private methods
msgSnippet: The way I see the problem of testing private methods is: for those of you who would like to see this feature in JUnit, try developing a nice working solution
messageBody:
The way I see the problem of testing private methods is:
for those of you who would like to see this feature in JUnit, try
developing a nice working solution that fits well into the existing
JUnit codebase. I'm sure that, if well presented, the JUnit team would
be willing to evaluate your solution and add it to a future release (is
this true guys?).

I believe that, if people want to test private methods (and this is an
issue that crops up frequently), they should be allowed to do so (if
such functionality is readilly available).

Many people on this list believe that unit testing the public API helps
the overall design of the system (low coupling, high cohesion, ...), and
helps decouple solutions from their different implementations. Many
interesting points and suggestions have been raised over this issue,
however, they belong to a Testing&Design discussion, not a Unit Testing
discussion.

In the light of Unit Testing, if people want to unit test private
methods, so be it. The JUnit documentation could point out some of the
issues and uses of Unit Tests and how they help with the overall design
of a system (they may already do so, but its been a while since I last
looked), but the tool is for Unit Testing, and as such, should allow
people to use it as they will, so long as they know what they are up to.

Manuel Amago.
